intro: Fimbristylis transiens, commonly known as the transient sedge, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to tropical and subtropical regions. It belongs to the Cyperaceae family, which includes sedges and related plants. The plant typically grows in wetlands, marshes, and other moist environments, where it thrives in partial to full shade. Its slender, grass-like leaves are usually arranged in three rows, characteristic of many sedges. Fimbristylis transiens produces small, inconspicuous flowers that are clustered in spikelets, contributing to its role in wetland ecosystems.
